R. FRENCH'S interesting article, entitled '`Upper Classmen and
Lower," which was published in the previous issue of the NEWSLETTER, brings up, among many things, the question of freshman
class election.
When a freshman class comes together for the first time to elect
its officers, it is more or less in a state of disorganization. In the
first place, as a usual thing, about one-half of the class shows up.
No one knows what he wants to do, and no one will keep quiet. But
worst of all, no one knows the rules of order. A chairman is hastily
appointed and the elections pushed through. If the election is held
certain
man's
house
or
back yard, as was done this year, this man may very possibly be
in a
elected president or vice-president. The other elections follow in the same haphazard way.

At Princeton, the freshmen class election is presided over by the president of the junior
class. This, indeed, seems to be d very good custom, and has many advantages. In the first
place, the freshmen, recognizing a leader, all come to the meeting; in the second place, the
freshmen are made to keep quiet and consequently consider the merits of the candidates; and,
last of all, the rules of order are strictly observed.
Now, if in the future the upper classmen at Hopkins are to assume more dignity and
responsibility, it seems that the introduction of this custom might form a good beginning.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

4

COLLEGE LIFE.
MURRAY P. BRUSH.

The college man who enters the graduate
school of the Johns Hopkins University for
the first time is invariably impressed by two
things. The first of these is the situation of
the University buildings, in the heart of the
city, hemmed in on all sides by red brick
walls rising from roughly-paved, ill-kept
streets, with an extensive view from the upper
windows of flat, tin roofs dotted with chimney
pots. But the graduate student conies here
for a definite purpose, his college days are
over, he has elected to become a specialist in
one way or another and be soon finds himself
so deep in his choSen field of work that he becomes oblivious to his surroundings, or if he
thinks of them it is to be glad that they do
not tempt him to relaxation or idleness.
With the undergraduate the case is entirely
different, to be sure he conies to college to
continue his studies and to fit himself to take
his place in the professional or industrial life
of the nation, but it is not yet time for him
to devote himself to one, particular subject,
his especial aim is the enlargement of his
mental horizon, the acquirement of a broad
culture which shall be a firm foundation to
build on in the future. The group system of
studies followed in college is directly intended
to aid in this general development of the
undergraduate student, in each group the
work is so arranged that no one may receive
the degree of bachelor of arts who has not
had training in mathematics, languages, history, and science, in addition to special training in the subjects most congenial to his
tastes. The various instructors, likewise,
take a deep interest in the broad development
of the student and do all in their power both
in the class-room and as advisers to keep him
from confining his studies to too narrow
limits.
But no boy becomes a man simply through
close attention to lectures and diligent perusal
of text-books, the real keynote of his development lies in his relation to other people, that
is, when he has entered college, to his fellowstudents. This brings me to the second
feature which impresses the entering graduate
student, the apparent lack of college life

and spirit in the undergraduate body as a
whole. The great majority of men who come
to the University as graduate students have
been living in an atmosphere where there was
just one object, one love in the student's life,
a love which filled his heart from his freshman
to his senior year, the welfare of his alma
mater. During the four long years at college
he has forgotten his school days at home when
his father used to tell him to run upstairs at
eight o'clock to study his lessons, while his
mother looked to see if he had put on his
rubbers on rainy mornings. His love and
respect for his father and mother have in no
wise diminished, in fact, he has just learned
really to appreciate what they are to him, but
he has learned to do his own thinking, to
rely on himself, he has become independent
and thereby free.
Of course, the change did not come about
all at once, many were the days, when he first
went to college, when he felt lonesome and
miserable, and when everything looked blue
to him. But by and by, he began to say to
himself like the oriental sage, 'This, too, will
pass," be made friends with the other men,
helped them to share their burdens and was
helped himself.
Here, at Hopkins, the case is altogether different, so many of the students live in town,
that very few indeed find themselves suddenly
dependent upon their own resources and
separated from all friends save the other members of their class, and often it results that
when things do not go just right to suit every
man, instead of trying to find out if the hitch
is not with himself, he simply goes home,
stays away from the rest of the crowd, and
remains a little school-boy to the end of his
college course. It is hardly necessary to say
that such a boy loses half the benefit as well
as all the fun of going to college, he would be
nearly as well off if he staid at home and
employed a tutor, he cannot develop as he
should without the fresh, joyous companionship of his equals. I know of but one case
sadder than his, the case of the American boy
who has been educated abroad and comes
back a stranger to live his later life in the
free, democratic bustle of his native land.
The graduate student, as said above,
notices on entering an apparent lack of college

5

THE NEWS-LETTER.

life,but that does not mean that there is no such
life here, simply that it manifests itself under
different conditions from those prevalent elsewhere. Situated as we are in the midst of a
great city, the noisy exuberance of the little
country collegian is beneath our dignity, we
do not wish to make our proud University
ridiculous in the eyes of her neighbors by
noisy street brawls or childish parades of the
freshmen; we can leave such pleasures to
second rate fraternal organizations, or darky
picnics.
No, the secret of real college life at Johns
Hopkins, as at any great city college, is found
in the independence of the individual students,
and, fortunately, they are not lacking, who
are manly enough not to yield to the pressure
of their surroundings, who triumph over unfavorable conditions, and who live their own
lives as freely and independently as if they
had only themselves to rely upon in times of
perplexity and sorrow. It is these bolder men
who really get the good out of life here; they
become the alumni that do not forget their
college; they are the men we are all proud of
in after life. In spite of the fact that they
live at home and have many ties and demands
upon their time that the man who lives in a
dormitory knows nothing of, they do not let
these things hold them back from taking part
in the various fields of college activity. As
freshmen they get together and form a strong
class organization in which the opposing factions will put the good of the class and of the
cpllege above their own petty desires, and
where everybody will pull together. They
join fraternities and play on the teams, if they
can, and when they do they are not too proud
to keep up a close friendship with less fortunate
members of the class. Above all, they stand
on their own merits and judge their classmates
by what they are and neither ask nor care
whether their great-grandfathers owned slaves
in Maryland or were pauper immigrants.
These college men, for they and they alone
have a right to the name, do not let outside,
social engagements interfere with anything
which may claim their presence at the University. They take their.best girls to the Hopkins dances, but do not spend every afternoon
sitting with them on their front steps, when
they might be helping along the cause of

J. H. U. by getting out to practice on the
football field or track. And when they go to
the games and to the theatre on Hopkins
Night they do not sit back and look on while
others do the cheering and singing.
And yet this is only one side of college life,
only a few of the many things we remember
in after days. The other side is equally attractive, the long talks with two or three
fellows around a good fire in the winter, or
by the water's edge in the spring, the long
walks on frosty afternoons through the woods
down toward Ilchester, or out around Loch
Raven, or the little intimate gatherings where
a few fellows get together and discuss things,
not people, and where you learn to stand up for
your own side, yet listen to the other man, too,
and get that broad-minded point of view which
will let you judge of a thing by what it is and
not by some preconceived prejudice or theory
of what it might be.
It is just such little things as these, taken
all together, the things in which we are
brought into close relations with the other
men, that go to make up the real life at college, and to live that life, to enjoy it, and to
benefit by it, we must forget ourselves, we
must put the college first and try to do all in
our power to promote its dignity and welfare.
And if we live thus for it, the four years of
college will be the happiest of our lives, and
we shall learn the real, true meaning of those
magic words, Alma Mater.

COTILLON CLUB.
The Cotillon Club has already had several
meetings, and is now busily engaged in preparations for the series of dances which it is
going to give this season. There will be three
dances, the first will be Friday, December
4th, the dates of the other two dances will
be published later. The dances will be held,as
usual, in McCoy Hall, which is one of the
largest ball rooms in the city. Since the
dances are always very enjoyable, they should
be well patronized this winter by graduate
and medical students as well as by undergraduates.
Several new members have been elected to
the Board of Governors. It now consists of
the following men:
President, F. Janney Smith, '09; Secretary,
Franklin B. Pedrick, '09; Treasurer, Howard
Michael, '09; F. K. Murray, '09; B. H.
Farber, '11; J. R. Manning, '11; Chauncey
B. Bosley, '11; E. B. Clary, '11; E. C.
Stollenwerck, '11; F. C. Lee, '12.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE PROPOSED INTER-FRATERNITY
TREATY.
BASED, IN GREAT PART, ON INTER-CLUB TREATIES
AT PRINCETON UNIVERSITY.

WHEREAS, The distinctive features of the
Johns Hopkins University Fraternity System
include a strict regard on the part of the several fraternities for the welfare of ungraduate
life at the University, and also a dignified reserve towards all possible candidates for membership in those fraternities; and
WHEREAS, It is realized that of late years
the practise of premature pledging, electioneering, "cradling" and "rushing" of prospective students of this University is and has
proved to be a source of detriment to the
dignity of fraternities, to the welfare of conditions of undergraduate life at this University,
and the state of mind of the prospective
students in question.
Now, THEREFORE, BE IT KNOWN, That we,
the subscribers, being certain of the fraternities of the Johns Hopkins University, for the
purposes of reforming said practises as far as
possible, and of preventing the Fraternity
System from becoming a detriment to the
University at large, do hereby enter into the
following treaty, viz. :

SEC. 3. The secretary shall keep minutes
of all meetings of the committee in permanent
form and exhibit the same to any member
thereof upon request. At the close of the
college year these minutes shall be deposited
in the University Library, properly bound.
SEC. 4. At all meetings of the committee,
each member present shall be entitled to one
vote; two-thirds of its members shall constitute
a quorum for the transaction of business; and
a majority vote of the whole committee shall
be necessary to any action.
SEC. 5. Subject to the specific provisions
of this treaty, the committee may, from time
time, adopt rules to regulate the transaction
of business and the conduct of investigations.
SEC. 6. The committee shall hold regular
meetings in each college year, as follows: Its
first meeting shall be held within two weeks
after the official opening of the University. It
shall then meet every eighth week. Special
meetings may be called by order of the chairman, and shall be so called upon request of
any two members of the committee; one day's
written or personal notice of each special
meeting shall be given to every member of the
committee. Notice of each regular meeting
shall be mailed by the secretary to every
member of the committee at least three days
prior to the date set therefor.

ARTICLE I.
Inter-Fraternity Committee.
SECTION 1. There shall be a committee,
known as the Inter-Fraternity Committee, consisting of two members from each fraternity
(such representatives to be chosen by the
separate fraternities), charged with carrying
out and enforcing all the provisions of this
treaty and having general oversight of its
operation.

SECTION 1. This treaty, or such portions
thereof as the Inter-Fraternity President shall
decide, shall be published in the NEWS-LETTER in its first and third issues of every year,
copies to be posted on the University bulletin
boards until November 25th of each year.

SEC. 2. The committee, at the last reuglar

SEC. 2. The chairman may, at his discretion,

meeting of each collegiate year, shall elect a
President, Vice-President and Secretary, to be
known, respectively, as the Inter-Fraternity
President, Inter-Fraternity Vice-President
and Inter-Fraternity Secretary. These officers
shall maintain an office for the transaction of
the committee's business, and shall keep
there on file, open to the inspection of the
members of the committee, all correspondence
and papers pertaining to the committee's
business, and all pledges and statements.

or shall upon the written request of one-fourth
of the committee, call mass-meetings of fraternity members for the purpose of discussing
matters relative to Inter-Fraternity management and the operation and enforcement of
this treaty.
ARTICLE III.
SECTION 1. No prospective student of this
University shall be permitted by any fraternity, fraternity member, or graduate member thereof, to enter a fraternity house before

March 1 of the year of his intended attendance
at the University.
SEC. 2. No fraternity, fraternity member,
or graduate member thereof, shall accept as
binding any promise, declaration or pledge of
any sort whatsoever from such prospective
student, that he will become or refrain from
becoming a member of any fraternity.
SEC. 3. Each signatory fraternity shall so
arrange that, at a time prior to noon of the
fortieth day after the official opening of the
University, the Inter-Fraternity Secretary
shall receive notice in writing of the names of
all students elected to membership. The
secretary shall thereupon, promptly notify
such persons of their election. The InterFraternity Secretary's notification to the
student shall contain a notice, as prescribed
in the next succeeding section.
SEC. 4. The notice mentioned in Article
III, Section 3, shall
(1). Contain announcement of the election
of the student to whom it is addressed.
(2). Instruct said student to mail to the
Inter-Fraternity Secretary, his acceptance or
declination of such election, within five days
o; the date thereof.
There shall be endorsed with every such
notice of election or elections, a blank form
for the pledge required by Article III, Section
5, of this treaty.
SEC. 5. Any student accepting such election, as provided in Section 3 and Section 4,
of Article III, to any fraternity, shall send
his acceptance to the secretary of the InterFraternity Committee, together with a signed
statement in the following form:
, of the Class
of
, having accepted an election to the
Fraternity, do hereby
solemnly pledge my word of honor that I have
never in any way either. pledged myself or in
any manner bound myself to become, or to
refrain from becoming, a member of any fraternity. I do also declare that prior to March
1 of the year above dated, I have not entered
the house of the Johns Hopkins chapter of
any fraternity.

7

And if any student receives notice of his
election to more than one fraternity, he shall
mail, at the same time with such acceptance,
his declination of each of the other elections.
In case of an election being extended to a
student in his second, third or fourth year of
residence at the University, the last clause in
the above pledge shall be changed to read:
"I do also declare that prior to March 1 of the
year of my intended attendance at the University, I have not entered the house of the
Johns Hopkins chapter of any fraternity."
SEC. 6. (a) Every acceptance, if accompanied by such a statement, and every declination must be immediately delivered to the
fraternity interested.
(b) In case any student accepts without
sending such statement, both he and the
fraternity whose election he has accepted
must be immediately notified that he can not
become a member of that fraternity until he
appears before the committee and makes a
satisfactory statement.
(c) In case any student who has been
notified, as prescribed in paragraph (b)of this
Section, appears before the committee and
states that he has been permitted, (before
March 1st of that year) to enter any fraternity
house or has been pledged by a certain member or members of the fraternity whose election he has accepted, such fraternity shall be
immediately notified in writing of such statement in full.
(d) In case any'student, not being able to
sign the pledge, refuses to give evidence,
which the Inter-Fraternity Committee shall
require, that student shall forego the privilege
of membership in any fraternity party to this
treaty, during the remainder of his college
course.
(e) But any sudent, found unable to sign
the pledge mentioned in Article III, Section
5, if adjudged by the Inter-Fraternity Committee to have acted unknowingly and through
failure of a fraternity, or fraternity member,
to inform him of the customs, shall be at liberty to accept and decline such invitations as
have been forwarded to him by the secretary,
but any previous pledge or promise to become,
or refrain from becoming, a member of any
fraternity, shall be absolutely null and void.

ARTICLE IV.
SECTION 1. The said Inter - Fraternity
Committee is hereby authorized to hear and
determine any circumstance or case which may
arise, involving membership in any fraternity,
which is not specifically provided for herein.
The said committee is ,hereby authorized to
investigate, hear and determine all infractions
of this treaty; and, to this end, to summon
witnesses and examine them upon their honor.
as to all matters affecting such investigation.
SEC. 2. Any member of the University,
graduate or uhdergraduate, having knowledge
or reasonable suspicion of any breach of the
provisions of this treaty, shall bring such facts
to the attention of the representatives of the
involved fraternity, and the president of the
Inter-Fraternity Committee.
The representatives of this fraternity shall
immediately investigate this case and report
the result of this investigation within ten days
to a meeting of the Inter-Fraternity Committee. The committee shall, if necessary,
continue the investigation and decide upon
the punishment.
ARTICLE V.
Second Annual Election.
SECTION 1. To provide for a second date
of election in every year, each signatory
fraternity shall, under the conditions of this
treaty, arrange so that at a time prior to noon
of January 2 )th, the Inter-Fraternity Secretary shall receive notice in writing of the
names of students elected to membership.
The secretary shall thereupon promptly notify
such persons of their election. The conditions concerning the secretary's notification
and the student's reply shall be identical with
those described in Articles III and IV.
ARTICLE VI.
ExPenses of the Inter-Fraternity Committee.
SECTION 1. The committee shall, from
time to time, levy equal pro rata assessments
upon the fraternities to meet the expenses
incident to carrying out and enforcing the
provisions of this treaty.
ARTICLE VII.
IViihdrawals.
SECTION 1. No fraternity can withdraw from
the treaty unless sixty days' written notice be

given before the withdrawal, signed by the
treasurer of the fraternity and the two representatives.
ARTICLE VIII.
Amendments.
SECTION 1. Any proposed amendment to
this treaty, approved by a vote of three-fourths
of the entire committee, shall be submitted to
the respective fraternities for action. The
undergraduate members of the fraternities shall
then, at separate meetings, to be held by each
fraternity, vote upon the question of whether
such proposed amendment shall be adopted or
rejected. A three-fourths vote of all the fraternities shall be necessary to render the
amendment effective. The secfetary shall,
immediately upon adoption, notify each fraternity of any amendment thereto.
ARTICLE IX.
Pledges.
SECTION 1. The officers of the InterFraternity Treaty Committee shall during the
first month of college cause the representatives
of every fraternity party to this agreement to
appear before them and make the following
pledge:
Pursuant to authority vested in me as reFraternity by a
presentative of the
resolution adopted by the active chapter of
said fraternity, I hereby pledge my word of
honor as a gentleman to uphold in every way
the best interests of Johns Hopkins University
regarding the social system, both as defined
in the regulations of the treaty and as decided
by the majority of the Inter-Fraternity Treaty
Committee, not only by my own actions but
by using every means in my power to insure
that the fraternity will act, and its individual
members will act, in the best interests of the
University as defined above.

WITNESS:
Signature of Representative.
ARTICLE X.
Construction.
SECTION 1. The construction of the provisions of this treaty shall, at all times, rest
with the members of the Inter-Fraternity Committee.

THE HAVERFORD GAME.
On the thirty-first of October the football
team went to Haverford. Like Cceser, renit,
vine/f. Of the game there is more to be
said than the limited amount of space allows.
Hopkins played the steadier, headier, game;
the excellent headwork of Stollenwerck at
quarter, the long punts of Michael and Fulton,
the defense work of McCabe, and the absolute
reliability of Musser getting down under kicks,
were probably the features which won for
Hopkins. While Haverford probably excelled
in line bucking, their inability to handle punts,
their continual fumbling, and the failure of
their tackles to stop Capt. Stockton and
Michael from breaking through the blocking
punts, lost the game for them. This last
cause, more than any other, led to Hopkins'
victory. Twice punts were blocked within
Haverford's twenty-yard line. One of these
resulted in a touchdown and the other in a
safety for Hopkins. The safety was the most
spectacular thing in the game. Bosley broke
through and blocked Haverford's punt, the
ball rolling under a wire fence, some
twenty yards back of Haverford's goal line.
Fulton, and Tomlinson of Haverford both
tried to jump the fence. Fulton succeeded,
but Tomlinson crashed into the fence. Everybody thought Fulton would get the ball, but
there was still an unaccounted-for factor in
the shape one small boy who picked up the
ball and threw it to Tomlinson. Hopkins'
claim of a touchdown on account of interfer-

9

.043)MISNIN
ance by the spectators was not allowed, it
being called a safety. The first half closed a
few minutes later, the score being Hopkins, 2;
Haverford, 0.
In the second half Hopkins kicked off to
Haverford's twenty-yard line. Haverford
then, by steady line plunges, carried the ball
to Hopkins' five-yard line. A cross buck
through tackle netted about six inches, and an
end run resulted in the loss of three yards.
Now, on third down with seven yards to gain,
Tomlinson went between for a touchdown.
After the kickoff, on an exchange of kicks,
it was Hopkins' ball on Haverford's twentyfive yard line. After two futile attempts to
gain through the line, Stollenwerck dropped
back and put a drop kick squarely between
the bars.
The game now resolved into a kicking dual,
Hopkins having a large advantage. Michael
blocked a punt on Haverford's twenty-five
yard line and Stockton fell on it for a touchdown.

GALLAUDET AND DELAWARE.
After meeting three strong, well-balanced
teams like Western Maryland, Stevens, and
Haverford, and coming through with a tie
score and two victories, the games with
Gallaudet and Delaware seem to be easy ones.
Gallaudet is not showing its usual form this
year, while Delaware, though probably as
good this year as last, has not advanced

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

much. We can truthfully say that the
'Varsity football team is better in every way
this year than last. Therefore, these two
games should be easy victories for the Black
and Blue.
Gallaudet, however, has a tendency to show
unexpected strength, for in a hard-fought
game they held Mount Washington to a
scoreless tie. On the following week the
Mutes took a slump and lost to the Maryland
Agriculture College, 5 to 0. On October
24th, Richmond College defeated Gallaudet,
16 to 12. This game showed that the Mutes
play especially strong in the second half, for
it was in that half that they scored their two
touchdowns. The latest lineup of Gallaudet
is as follows:

Right tackle—Isaacson.
Right end—Mosey.

Right halfback—Baily, Arras.
Fullback—Birk.
Last year Delaware College held us to a
0 to 0 tie, but this year we sincerely hope
and are almost certain that the result will be
different. Delaware has not made a brilliant
record this season, having lost three out of
the four games played. Williamson, Haverford and Bucknell all won from the Newark
team. Delaware's single victory came on
October 31st, when she defeated Washington
College, 12 to 0. Haley, at fullback is their

THE CROSS COUNTRY MEET.
The Cross Country Club held its first run
of the season at Homewood on October 31st.
Teams from the Washington Grove Club,
McCulloh's, Cross Country Club, Washington and Hopkins ran, making a total of about
thirty competitors. In spite of the high wind
and the hilly character of the course, the runners succeeded in making very good time.
Johns Hopkins was represented by a team
of seven men, Capt. Breyer, Griffith, Reeside,
Russell, Tappan, Stockett and Hulburt, and
all of these finished the race in good shape.
Griffith won first place by an ample margin,
in the time of thirty-four minutes and sixteen

these men were scratch, but their running was
so superior to th other competitors that they
passed the limit handicap men after about two

eighth and tenth respectively, and are to be
congratulated on their fine showing.
A banner was given to the team of four men
scoring the minimum number of points and
Hopkins won the trophy. In addition, Griffith
was awarded a handsome gold watch and
Breyer a silver medal.
The Cross Country Team, under the able
leadership of Capt. Breyer, will continue
training for the Washington meet on January
1st. If you can run, come out and try for it;
if you can't, at least come out and root.
Cross country runners need rooting just as
much as football or lacrosse players. Support
all the teams, and Hopkins will win.

UNIVERSITY NOTES.
The University Delmonico's has re-opened
in its recently altered quarters in the basement of McCoy Hall, and the same old brand
of sandwiches is on tap.

THE FRENCH REVOLUTION.
Ernest Flagg Henderson, Ph.D., L.H.D.,
of Cambridge, Mass., will give lectures on
"The French Revolution," in McCoy Hall,
Tuesdays, at 5 P. M., beginning November
10th. The topics and dates are as follows:
November 10th—The Old Regime.
November 17th—The Third Estate.
November 24th—The Queen and the Constitution.
December 1st—The Fall of Royalty.
December 8th—The Girondists and Charlotte Corday.
December 15th—The Regime o f Robespierre.
The lectures will be illustrated by about
four hundred slides, including all sorts of
contemporaneous representations: buildings,
portraits, newspaper illustrations, caricatures,
official documents, autograph letters, etc.
They are for the most part directly from the
originals in the Paris and Versailles Museums
and in the National Archives.
Cards of admission will not be required.

R. FRENCH'S interesting article, entitled '`Upper Classmen and
Lower," which was published in the previous issue of the NEWSLETTER, brings up, among many things, the question of freshman
class election.
When a freshman class comes together for the first time to elect
its officers, it is more or less in a state of disorganization. In the
first place, as a usual thing, about one-half of the class shows up.
No one knows what he wants to do, and no one will keep quiet. But
worst of all, no one knows the rules of order. A chairman is hastily
appointed and the elections pushed through. If the election is held
certain
man's
house
or
back yard, as was done this year, this man may very possibly be
in a
elected president or vice-president. The other elections follow in the same haphazard way.

At Princeton, the freshmen class election is presided over by the president of the junior
class. This, indeed, seems to be d very good custom, and has many advantages. In the first
place, the freshmen, recognizing a leader, all come to the meeting; in the second place, the
freshmen are made to keep quiet and consequently consider the merits of the candidates; and,
last of all, the rules of order are strictly observed.
Now, if in the future the upper classmen at Hopkins are to assume more dignity and
responsibility, it seems that the introduction of this custom might form a good beginning.

COLLEGE LIFE.
MURRAY P. BRUSH.

The college man who enters the graduate
school of the Johns Hopkins University for
the first time is invariably impressed by two
things. The first of these is the situation of
the University buildings, in the heart of the
city, hemmed in on all sides by red brick
walls rising from roughly-paved, ill-kept
streets, with an extensive view from the upper
windows of flat, tin roofs dotted with chimney
pots. But the graduate student conies here
for a definite purpose, his college days are
over, he has elected to become a specialist in
one way or another and be soon finds himself
so deep in his choSen field of work that he becomes oblivious to his surroundings, or if he
thinks of them it is to be glad that they do
not tempt him to relaxation or idleness.
With the undergraduate the case is entirely
different, to be sure he conies to college to
continue his studies and to fit himself to take
his place in the professional or industrial life
of the nation, but it is not yet time for him
to devote himself to one, particular subject,
his especial aim is the enlargement of his
mental horizon, the acquirement of a broad
culture which shall be a firm foundation to
build on in the future. The group system of
studies followed in college is directly intended
to aid in this general development of the
undergraduate student, in each group the
work is so arranged that no one may receive
the degree of bachelor of arts who has not
had training in mathematics, languages, history, and science, in addition to special training in the subjects most congenial to his
tastes. The various instructors, likewise,
take a deep interest in the broad development
of the student and do all in their power both
in the class-room and as advisers to keep him
from confining his studies to too narrow
limits.
But no boy becomes a man simply through
close attention to lectures and diligent perusal
of text-books, the real keynote of his development lies in his relation to other people, that
is, when he has entered college, to his fellowstudents. This brings me to the second
feature which impresses the entering graduate
student, the apparent lack of college life

and spirit in the undergraduate body as a
whole. The great majority of men who come
to the University as graduate students have
been living in an atmosphere where there was
just one object, one love in the student's life,
a love which filled his heart from his freshman
to his senior year, the welfare of his alma
mater. During the four long years at college
he has forgotten his school days at home when
his father used to tell him to run upstairs at
eight o'clock to study his lessons, while his
mother looked to see if he had put on his
rubbers on rainy mornings. His love and
respect for his father and mother have in no
wise diminished, in fact, he has just learned
really to appreciate what they are to him, but
he has learned to do his own thinking, to
rely on himself, he has become independent
and thereby free.
Of course, the change did not come about
all at once, many were the days, when he first
went to college, when he felt lonesome and
miserable, and when everything looked blue
to him. But by and by, he began to say to
himself like the oriental sage, 'This, too, will
pass," be made friends with the other men,
helped them to share their burdens and was
helped himself.
Here, at Hopkins, the case is altogether different, so many of the students live in town,
that very few indeed find themselves suddenly
dependent upon their own resources and
separated from all friends save the other members of their class, and often it results that
when things do not go just right to suit every
man, instead of trying to find out if the hitch
is not with himself, he simply goes home,
stays away from the rest of the crowd, and
remains a little school-boy to the end of his
college course. It is hardly necessary to say
that such a boy loses half the benefit as well
as all the fun of going to college, he would be
nearly as well off if he staid at home and
employed a tutor, he cannot develop as he
should without the fresh, joyous companionship of his equals. I know of but one case
sadder than his, the case of the American boy
who has been educated abroad and comes
back a stranger to live his later life in the
free, democratic bustle of his native land.
The graduate student, as said above,
notices on entering an apparent lack of college

5

THE NEWS-LETTER.

life,but that does not mean that there is no such
life here, simply that it manifests itself under
different conditions from those prevalent elsewhere. Situated as we are in the midst of a
great city, the noisy exuberance of the little
country collegian is beneath our dignity, we
do not wish to make our proud University
ridiculous in the eyes of her neighbors by
noisy street brawls or childish parades of the
freshmen; we can leave such pleasures to
second rate fraternal organizations, or darky
picnics.
No, the secret of real college life at Johns
Hopkins, as at any great city college, is found
in the independence of the individual students,
and, fortunately, they are not lacking, who
are manly enough not to yield to the pressure
of their surroundings, who triumph over unfavorable conditions, and who live their own
lives as freely and independently as if they
had only themselves to rely upon in times of
perplexity and sorrow. It is these bolder men
who really get the good out of life here; they
become the alumni that do not forget their
college; they are the men we are all proud of
in after life. In spite of the fact that they
live at home and have many ties and demands
upon their time that the man who lives in a
dormitory knows nothing of, they do not let
these things hold them back from taking part
in the various fields of college activity. As
freshmen they get together and form a strong
class organization in which the opposing factions will put the good of the class and of the
cpllege above their own petty desires, and
where everybody will pull together. They
join fraternities and play on the teams, if they
can, and when they do they are not too proud
to keep up a close friendship with less fortunate
members of the class. Above all, they stand
on their own merits and judge their classmates
by what they are and neither ask nor care
whether their great-grandfathers owned slaves
in Maryland or were pauper immigrants.
These college men, for they and they alone
have a right to the name, do not let outside,
social engagements interfere with anything
which may claim their presence at the University. They take their.best girls to the Hopkins dances, but do not spend every afternoon
sitting with them on their front steps, when
they might be helping along the cause of

J. H. U. by getting out to practice on the
football field or track. And when they go to
the games and to the theatre on Hopkins
Night they do not sit back and look on while
others do the cheering and singing.
And yet this is only one side of college life,
only a few of the many things we remember
in after days. The other side is equally attractive, the long talks with two or three
fellows around a good fire in the winter, or
by the water's edge in the spring, the long
walks on frosty afternoons through the woods
down toward Ilchester, or out around Loch
Raven, or the little intimate gatherings where
a few fellows get together and discuss things,
not people, and where you learn to stand up for
your own side, yet listen to the other man, too,
and get that broad-minded point of view which
will let you judge of a thing by what it is and
not by some preconceived prejudice or theory
of what it might be.
It is just such little things as these, taken
all together, the things in which we are
brought into close relations with the other
men, that go to make up the real life at college, and to live that life, to enjoy it, and to
benefit by it, we must forget ourselves, we
must put the college first and try to do all in
our power to promote its dignity and welfare.
And if we live thus for it, the four years of
college will be the happiest of our lives, and
we shall learn the real, true meaning of those
magic words, Alma Mater.

COTILLON CLUB.
The Cotillon Club has already had several
meetings, and is now busily engaged in preparations for the series of dances which it is
going to give this season. There will be three
dances, the first will be Friday, December
4th, the dates of the other two dances will
be published later. The dances will be held,as
usual, in McCoy Hall, which is one of the
largest ball rooms in the city. Since the
dances are always very enjoyable, they should
be well patronized this winter by graduate
and medical students as well as by undergraduates.
Several new members have been elected to
the Board of Governors. It now consists of
the following men:
President, F. Janney Smith, '09; Secretary,
Franklin B. Pedrick, '09; Treasurer, Howard
Michael, '09; F. K. Murray, '09; B. H.
Farber, '11; J. R. Manning, '11; Chauncey
B. Bosley, '11; E. B. Clary, '11; E. C.
Stollenwerck, '11; F. C. Lee, '12.

THE PROPOSED INTER-FRATERNITY
TREATY.
BASED, IN GREAT PART, ON INTER-CLUB TREATIES
AT PRINCETON UNIVERSITY.

WHEREAS, The distinctive features of the
Johns Hopkins University Fraternity System
include a strict regard on the part of the several fraternities for the welfare of ungraduate
life at the University, and also a dignified reserve towards all possible candidates for membership in those fraternities; and
WHEREAS, It is realized that of late years
the practise of premature pledging, electioneering, "cradling" and "rushing" of prospective students of this University is and has
proved to be a source of detriment to the
dignity of fraternities, to the welfare of conditions of undergraduate life at this University,
and the state of mind of the prospective
students in question.
Now, THEREFORE, BE IT KNOWN, That we,
the subscribers, being certain of the fraternities of the Johns Hopkins University, for the
purposes of reforming said practises as far as
possible, and of preventing the Fraternity
System from becoming a detriment to the
University at large, do hereby enter into the
following treaty, viz. :

SEC. 3. The secretary shall keep minutes
of all meetings of the committee in permanent
form and exhibit the same to any member
thereof upon request. At the close of the
college year these minutes shall be deposited
in the University Library, properly bound.
SEC. 4. At all meetings of the committee,
each member present shall be entitled to one
vote; two-thirds of its members shall constitute
a quorum for the transaction of business; and
a majority vote of the whole committee shall
be necessary to any action.
SEC. 5. Subject to the specific provisions
of this treaty, the committee may, from time
time, adopt rules to regulate the transaction
of business and the conduct of investigations.
SEC. 6. The committee shall hold regular
meetings in each college year, as follows: Its
first meeting shall be held within two weeks
after the official opening of the University. It
shall then meet every eighth week. Special
meetings may be called by order of the chairman, and shall be so called upon request of
any two members of the committee; one day's
written or personal notice of each special
meeting shall be given to every member of the
committee. Notice of each regular meeting
shall be mailed by the secretary to every
member of the committee at least three days
prior to the date set therefor.

ARTICLE I.
Inter-Fraternity Committee.
SECTION 1. There shall be a committee,
known as the Inter-Fraternity Committee, consisting of two members from each fraternity
(such representatives to be chosen by the
separate fraternities), charged with carrying
out and enforcing all the provisions of this
treaty and having general oversight of its
operation.

SECTION 1. This treaty, or such portions
thereof as the Inter-Fraternity President shall
decide, shall be published in the NEWS-LETTER in its first and third issues of every year,
copies to be posted on the University bulletin
boards until November 25th of each year.

SEC. 2. The committee, at the last reuglar

known, respectively, as the Inter-Fraternity
President, Inter-Fraternity Vice-President

shall maintain an office for the transaction of
the committee's business, and shall keep
there on file, open to the inspection of the

ARTICLE IV.
SECTION 1. The said Inter - Fraternity
Committee is hereby authorized to hear and
determine any circumstance or case which may
arise, involving membership in any fraternity,
which is not specifically provided for herein.
The said committee is ,hereby authorized to
investigate, hear and determine all infractions
of this treaty; and, to this end, to summon
witnesses and examine them upon their honor.
as to all matters affecting such investigation.
SEC. 2. Any member of the University,
graduate or uhdergraduate, having knowledge
or reasonable suspicion of any breach of the
provisions of this treaty, shall bring such facts
to the attention of the representatives of the
involved fraternity, and the president of the
Inter-Fraternity Committee.
The representatives of this fraternity shall
immediately investigate this case and report
the result of this investigation within ten days
to a meeting of the Inter-Fraternity Committee. The committee shall, if necessary,
continue the investigation and decide upon
the punishment.
ARTICLE V.
Second Annual Election.
SECTION 1. To provide for a second date
of election in every year, each signatory
fraternity shall, under the conditions of this
treaty, arrange so that at a time prior to noon
of January 2 )th, the Inter-Fraternity Secretary shall receive notice in writing of the
names of students elected to membership.
The secretary shall thereupon promptly notify
such persons of their election. The conditions concerning the secretary's notification
and the student's reply shall be identical with
those described in Articles III and IV.
ARTICLE VI.
ExPenses of the Inter-Fraternity Committee.
SECTION 1. The committee shall, from
time to time, levy equal pro rata assessments
upon the fraternities to meet the expenses
incident to carrying out and enforcing the
provisions of this treaty.
ARTICLE VII.
IViihdrawals.
SECTION 1. No fraternity can withdraw from
the treaty unless sixty days' written notice be

given before the withdrawal, signed by the
treasurer of the fraternity and the two representatives.
ARTICLE VIII.
Amendments.
SECTION 1. Any proposed amendment to
this treaty, approved by a vote of three-fourths
of the entire committee, shall be submitted to
the respective fraternities for action. The
undergraduate members of the fraternities shall
then, at separate meetings, to be held by each
fraternity, vote upon the question of whether
such proposed amendment shall be adopted or
rejected. A three-fourths vote of all the fraternities shall be necessary to render the
amendment effective. The secfetary shall,
immediately upon adoption, notify each fraternity of any amendment thereto.
ARTICLE IX.
Pledges.
SECTION 1. The officers of the InterFraternity Treaty Committee shall during the
first month of college cause the representatives
of every fraternity party to this agreement to
appear before them and make the following
pledge:
Pursuant to authority vested in me as reFraternity by a
presentative of the
resolution adopted by the active chapter of
said fraternity, I hereby pledge my word of
honor as a gentleman to uphold in every way
the best interests of Johns Hopkins University
regarding the social system, both as defined
in the regulations of the treaty and as decided
by the majority of the Inter-Fraternity Treaty
Committee, not only by my own actions but
by using every means in my power to insure
that the fraternity will act, and its individual
members will act, in the best interests of the
University as defined above.

WITNESS:
Signature of Representative.
ARTICLE X.
Construction.
SECTION 1. The construction of the provisions of this treaty shall, at all times, rest
with the members of the Inter-Fraternity Committee.

THE HAVERFORD GAME.
On the thirty-first of October the football
team went to Haverford. Like Cceser, renit,
vine/f. Of the game there is more to be
said than the limited amount of space allows.
Hopkins played the steadier, headier, game;
the excellent headwork of Stollenwerck at
quarter, the long punts of Michael and Fulton,
the defense work of McCabe, and the absolute
reliability of Musser getting down under kicks,
were probably the features which won for
Hopkins. While Haverford probably excelled
in line bucking, their inability to handle punts,
their continual fumbling, and the failure of
their tackles to stop Capt. Stockton and
Michael from breaking through the blocking
punts, lost the game for them. This last
cause, more than any other, led to Hopkins'
victory. Twice punts were blocked within
Haverford's twenty-yard line. One of these
resulted in a touchdown and the other in a
safety for Hopkins. The safety was the most
spectacular thing in the game. Bosley broke
through and blocked Haverford's punt, the
ball rolling under a wire fence, some
twenty yards back of Haverford's goal line.
Fulton, and Tomlinson of Haverford both
tried to jump the fence. Fulton succeeded,
but Tomlinson crashed into the fence. Everybody thought Fulton would get the ball, but
there was still an unaccounted-for factor in
the shape one small boy who picked up the
ball and threw it to Tomlinson. Hopkins'
claim of a touchdown on account of interfer-

9

.043)MISNIN
ance by the spectators was not allowed, it
being called a safety. The first half closed a
few minutes later, the score being Hopkins, 2;
Haverford, 0.
In the second half Hopkins kicked off to
Haverford's twenty-yard line. Haverford
then, by steady line plunges, carried the ball
to Hopkins' five-yard line. A cross buck
through tackle netted about six inches, and an
end run resulted in the loss of three yards.
Now, on third down with seven yards to gain,
Tomlinson went between for a touchdown.
After the kickoff, on an exchange of kicks,
it was Hopkins' ball on Haverford's twentyfive yard line. After two futile attempts to
gain through the line, Stollenwerck dropped
back and put a drop kick squarely between
the bars.
The game now resolved into a kicking dual,
Hopkins having a large advantage. Michael
blocked a punt on Haverford's twenty-five
yard line and Stockton fell on it for a touchdown.

GALLAUDET AND DELAWARE.
After meeting three strong, well-balanced
teams like Western Maryland, Stevens, and
Haverford, and coming through with a tie
score and two victories, the games with
Gallaudet and Delaware seem to be easy ones.
Gallaudet is not showing its usual form this
year, while Delaware, though probably as
good this year as last, has not advanced

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

much. We can truthfully say that the
'Varsity football team is better in every way
this year than last. Therefore, these two
games should be easy victories for the Black
and Blue.
Gallaudet, however, has a tendency to show
unexpected strength, for in a hard-fought
game they held Mount Washington to a
scoreless tie. On the following week the
Mutes took a slump and lost to the Maryland
Agriculture College, 5 to 0. On October
24th, Richmond College defeated Gallaudet,
16 to 12. This game showed that the Mutes
play especially strong in the second half, for
it was in that half that they scored their two
touchdowns. The latest lineup of Gallaudet
is as follows:

Left tackle—Gardner.

Center—Bell.
Right guard—Caldwell.
Right tackle—Isaacson.
Right end—Mosey.
Quarterback-0'Donnell.
Left halfback—McInnis.
Right halfback—Baily, Arras.
Fullback—Birk.
Last year Delaware College held us to a
0 to 0 tie, but this year we sincerely hope
and are almost certain that the result will be
different. Delaware has not made a brilliant
record this season, having lost three out of
the four games played. Williamson, Haverford and Bucknell all won from the Newark
team. Delaware's single victory came on
October 31st, when she defeated Washington
College, 12 to 0. Haley, at fullback is their
best offensive player, while Edwards, at right
tackle, is strong in both offensive and defensive work. Their latest lineup:

Center—Popperman,Captain ; Carswell.
Right guard—Doane.
Right tackle—Edwards.
Right end—Cann, Kidd.
Quarterback—Josephs, Greenwood.
Left halfback—Adkins.
Right halfback—Stewart.
Fullback—Haley.

THE CROSS COUNTRY MEET.
The Cross Country Club held its first run
of the season at Homewood on October 31st.
Teams from the Washington Grove Club,
McCulloh's, Cross Country Club, Washington and Hopkins ran, making a total of about
thirty competitors. In spite of the high wind
and the hilly character of the course, the runners succeeded in making very good time.
Johns Hopkins was represented by a team
of seven men, Capt. Breyer, Griffith, Reeside,
Russell, Tappan, Stockett and Hulburt, and
all of these finished the race in good shape.
Griffith won first place by an ample margin,
in the time of thirty-four minutes and sixteen

so superior to th other competitors that they

A banner was given to the team of four men

Hopkins won the trophy. In addition, Griffith
was awarded a handsome gold watch and

The Cross Country Team, under the able
leadership of Capt. Breyer, will continue
training for the Washington meet on January
1st. If you can run, come out and try for it;
if you can't, at least come out and root.
Cross country runners need rooting just as
much as football or lacrosse players. Support
all the teams, and Hopkins will win.

UNIVERSITY NOTES.
The University Delmonico's has re-opened
in its recently altered quarters in the basement of McCoy Hall, and the same old brand
of sandwiches is on tap.

THE FRENCH REVOLUTION.
Ernest Flagg Henderson, Ph.D., L.H.D.,
of Cambridge, Mass., will give lectures on
"The French Revolution," in McCoy Hall,
Tuesdays, at 5 P. M., beginning November
10th. The topics and dates are as follows:
November 10th—The Old Regime.
November 17th—The Third Estate.
November 24th—The Queen and the Constitution.
December 1st—The Fall of Royalty.
December 8th—The Girondists and Charlotte Corday.
December 15th—The Regime o f Robespierre.
The lectures will be illustrated by about
four hundred slides, including all sorts of
contemporaneous representations: buildings,
portraits, newspaper illustrations, caricatures,
official documents, autograph letters, etc.
They are for the most part directly from the
originals in the Paris and Versailles Museums
and in the National Archives.
Cards of admission will not be required.

ALUMNI NOTES.
The repairs to the stock room and corridor,
damaged by fire, are in progress. A new
ceiling has been put up in the corridor, and it
is hoped, that everything will be finished
soon.
It is a perpetual joy to the initiated to
watch the unwise wait patiently at the wrong
elevator shaft on the first day of every month.
